subgroups

subgroups.Rmd
library(safetymeta)
library(meta)
#> Loading required package: metadat
#> Loading 'meta' package (version 7.0-0).
#> Type 'help(meta)' for a brief overview.
#> Readers of 'Meta-Analysis with R (Use R!)' should install
#> older version of 'meta' package: https://tinyurl.com/dt4y5drs

You can perform subgroup analyses in meta. It is very common to have more than one subgroup analysis to run.

The metabin_wrap function is a very simple wrapper around meta::metabin to perform all subgroup analyses at once.

tnsc_data |>
  dplyr::filter(term_name == "myocardial_infarction") |>
  metabin_wrap(
    event_colnames = c("event_e", "event_c"),
    n_colnames = c("n_e", "n_c"),
    by_var = c("byvar1", "byvar2"),
    stud_lab = "study_id"
  )
#> $byvar1
#> Number of studies: k = 2
#> Number of observations: o = 96 (o.e = 47, o.c = 49)
#> Number of events: e = 11
#> 
#>                          RR           95%-CI    z p-value
#> Common effect model  2.7776 [0.7850; 9.8284] 1.58  0.1131
#> Random effects model 2.7683 [0.7819; 9.8007] 1.58  0.1144
#> 
#> Quantifying heterogeneity:
#>  tau^2 = 0; tau = 0; I^2 = 0.0%; H = 1.00
#> 
#> Test of heterogeneity:
#>     Q d.f. p-value
#>  0.02    1  0.8865
#> 
#> Results for subgroups (common effect model):
#>              k     RR            95%-CI    Q I^2
#> byvar1 = a   1 3.1500 [0.3565; 27.8310] 0.00  --
#> byvar1 = b   1 2.5926 [0.5490; 12.2427] 0.00  --
#> 
#> Test for subgroup differences (common effect model):
#>                   Q d.f. p-value
#> Between groups 0.02    1  0.8865
#> 
#> Results for subgroups (random effects model):
#>              k     RR            95%-CI tau^2 tau
#> byvar1 = a   1 3.1500 [0.3565; 27.8310]    --  --
#> byvar1 = b   1 2.5926 [0.5490; 12.2427]    --  --
#> 
#> Test for subgroup differences (random effects model):
#>                   Q d.f. p-value
#> Between groups 0.02    1  0.8865
#> 
#> Details on meta-analytical method:
#> - Mantel-Haenszel method (common effect model)
#> - Inverse variance method (random effects model)
#> - Restricted maximum-likelihood estimator for tau^2
#> 
#> $byvar2
#> Number of studies: k = 2
#> Number of observations: o = 96 (o.e = 47, o.c = 49)
#> Number of events: e = 11
#> 
#>                          RR           95%-CI    z p-value
#> Common effect model  2.7776 [0.7850; 9.8284] 1.58  0.1131
#> Random effects model 2.7683 [0.7819; 9.8007] 1.58  0.1144
#> 
#> Quantifying heterogeneity:
#>  tau^2 = 0; tau = 0; I^2 = 0.0%; H = 1.00
#> 
#> Test of heterogeneity:
#>     Q d.f. p-value
#>  0.02    1  0.8865
#> 
#> Results for subgroups (common effect model):
#>              k     RR           95%-CI    Q  I^2
#> byvar2 = a   2 2.7776 [0.7850; 9.8284] 0.02 0.0%
#> 
#> Test for subgroup differences (common effect model):
#>                   Q d.f. p-value
#> Between groups 0.00    0      --
#> 
#> Results for subgroups (random effects model):
#>              k     RR           95%-CI tau^2 tau
#> byvar2 = a   2 2.7683 [0.7819; 9.8007]     0   0
#> 
#> Test for subgroup differences (random effects model):
#>                   Q d.f. p-value
#> Between groups 0.00    0      --
#> 
#> Details on meta-analytical method:
#> - Mantel-Haenszel method (common effect model)
#> - Inverse variance method (random effects model)
#> - Restricted maximum-likelihood estimator for tau^2

The output is a named list, each element being a meta::metabin model.

This list can easily be passed to table_mod_summary to vignette("collect data").

Developed by Charles Dolladille, Pierre-Marie Morice.
